Marker graph appearance is defined by three properties: , and . Data series are specified using property.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Research.DynamicDataDisplay.Palette.Parse(System.String)
member.summary:
Parses the palette from the string.
String can contain: names of colors ( or hexadecimal representation #AARRGGBB), double values and separators (equal symbol or comma) to separate colors and values from each other.
Comma is used for gradient colors, equal symbol - for initializing a color of specified value.
Palette can be normalized or absolute.
Absolute palette maps entire numbers to colors exactly as numbers are specified. For examples, palette '-10=Blue,Green,Yellow,Red=10' maps values -10 and below to Blue, 10 and above to red.
Normalized palette maps minimum value to left palette color, maximum value to right palette color. In normalized palette no numbers on left and right sides are specified.
Palettes can contain regions of constant color. For example, palette 'Blue=0.25=Yellow=0.5=#00FF00=0.75=Orange' maps first quarter of values to blue, second quarter to yellow and so on.
